AFFIRMED


  
    
      
William 
  Isaac Diggs, of Myrtle Beach, for Appellant.
William L. Pope, 
  of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


ANDERSON, J.:Â  Tamera Bergstrom sued Palmetto Health Alliance (â€œthe hospitalâ€) 
  alleging the hospital was negligent and committed the tort of intentional infliction 
  of emotional distress regarding her purported adoption in 1979.Â  The hospital 
  moved to dismiss the claims and filed a motion to cap the hospitalâ€™s liability 
  at $100,000.Â  The Circuit Court granted the hospitalâ€™s motion to dismiss the 
  intentional infliction of emotional distress claim and the motion to cap damages 
  to $100,000.Â  The Circuit Court denied the hospitalâ€™s motion to dismiss the 
  negligence claim.
At trial, the hospital moved for directed verdict on the negligence claim at 
  the close of the presentation of Bergstromâ€™s evidence.Â  The Circuit Court granted 
  the directed verdict motion.Â  Bergstrom appeals the grant of the hospitalâ€™s 
  motions for: (1) directed verdict on the negligence claim; (2) dismissal of 
  the intentional infliction of emotional distress claim; and (3) limitation on 
  the hospitalâ€™s liability to $100,000.Â  We affirm.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Tamera Bergstrom was born on November 16, 1979, at Baptist Medical Center in 
  Columbia.Â  In early 1979, Debbie Daly, [1]  Bergstromâ€™s natural 
  mother, became pregnant.Â  Daly was seventeen years old, unmarried, and living 
  at Murrells Inlet.Â  Daly discussed her predicament with a coworker who introduced 
  her to Mary Andrews, the coworkerâ€™s mother.Â  After speaking with Andrews, Daly 
  began considering placing the baby for adoption.Â  When Daly was six and one-half 
  months into her pregnancy, she visited Andrews in Columbia and lived with her 
  for one week.
During the week Daly lived with Andrews, Andrews took Daly to meet with attorney 
  Joel Padgett where they discussed placing the baby for adoption. Daly did not 
  remember signing any adoption papers at this meeting.Â  Padgett suggested Daly 
  move in with Claire Wilson.Â  Wilson allowed Daly to stay with her in her home 
  rent and expense free until Daly went to the hospital to deliver the baby.Â  
  While living with Wilson, Daly was told the baby was to be adopted by a hospital 
  administrator and his wife, who was a nurse.Â  Daly was informed that this couple 
  had already adopted three children and would be good parents for the baby.
Daly 
  went to Baptist Medical Center to deliver the baby.Â  Daly testified that the 
  choice of hospital and medical doctors was arranged by Padgett and she had no 
  input in the decision.Â  She stated she never discussed adoption with any of 
  the doctors prior to going to the hospital to deliver the baby.Â  Daly delivered 
  Bergstrom at 7:57 p.m.Â  She was administered anesthesia in the delivery room.Â  
  Daly never saw Bergstrom.
The hospital had procedures in place at the time to govern the conduct of 
  hospital employees in adoption situations.Â  These policies read:
ADOPTION
DEFINITION AND PURPOSE

  
To provide 
  service for those mothers who wish to consider adoption for their newborn.
POLICY
1.Â  Have 
  the mother sign â€œPermitâ€ to Release Baby for Adoption.
2.Â  The 
  mother and/or her immediate family may see the infant at any time prior to discharge.
3.Â  Adoptive 
  parents are not to see the infant while the baby is in the hospital.
4.Â  A 
  social service referral should be made if the mother has not made previous arrangements.
5.Â  Have 
  attorney or caseworker sign circumcision permit for male infants.
RESPONSIBLE 
  PERSONS
RN, LPN, 
  Unit Manager
GENERAL 
  INSTRUCTIONS
1.Â  Call 
  Social Service Department at BMCC if there are questions about adoption.
2.Â  In 
  private adoptions, have attorney ask adoptive parents if they would like a Home 
  Health Referral for baby care instructions.
3.Â  Mother 
  may view infant through the nursery window or in her room if she requests.
4.Â  Motherâ€™s 
  immediate family may view the infant through the nursery window.
PROCEDURE
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
  . . . .
1.Â  Notify 
  the Unit Manager when mother is ready to sign â€œPermit for Release of Baby for 
  Adoption.â€
2.Â  Two 
  original forms must be signed.Â  Place one copy on the motherâ€™s chart and one 
  copy on the babyâ€™s chart.
3. Give 
  discharge instruction to attorney or caseworker.
4.Â  Release 
  baby to attorney or caseworker following Dismissal of Newborn Procedure.
  

On the day following Bergstromâ€™s birth, Daly began to have second thoughts about 
  placing Bergstrom for adoption.Â  On the third day after the delivery, the day 
  Daly was to leave the hospital, she decided she wanted to see Bergstrom.Â  When 
  Daly asked whether she could see the baby, the nurse responded, â€œ[a]re you the 
  adopting parent?â€Â  When Daly answered no, the nurse told her â€œthe baby was being 
  placed up for adoption and that [she] couldnâ€™t see the child.â€
Daly 
  returned to her room and began crying.Â  When Wilson arrived to pick Daly up, 
  she asked why Daly was crying.Â  Daly told her the hospital would not let her 
  see the baby and that she did not want to give the baby up for adoption. Wilson 
  told Daly there was nothing Daly could do at that point, the papers had already 
  been signed, and the adoption was final.Â  Daly testified that, during the length 
  of her stay at the hospital, none of the hospital staff came and spoke with 
  her about the adoption.Â  Daly stated Wilson told her she needed to sign a release 
  form before she left the hospital.Â  As Daly was leaving the hospital, she signed 
  the form, which provided:

PERMISSION TO RELEASE 
  BABY TO PARTY OTHER THAN MOTHER
  
I, the 
  undersigned, mother of Baby Gardner, [Dalyâ€™s maiden name] who was born in the 
  South Carolina Baptist Hospital, Columbia, South Carolina on 11/16/79, hereby 
  authorize and direct the . . . [h]ospital to release and deliver said baby to 
  Joel Padgett (Atty) or his or her agents and release and discharge [the hospital] 
  from any claims on account of such release and delivery.
It has 
  been fully explained to me and I understand that this does not in any way affect 
  the permanent custody of my child and is given for the purpose of authorizing 
  the [hospital] to permit the person named above to remove my child from the 
  hospital as an accommodation to me. 
  

After 
  signing the form, Daly left the hospital and stayed with Wilson for three weeks 
  before returning to Murrells Inlet.Â  Daly did not see Bergstrom before leaving.
Padgettâ€™s initial plan to have the baby adopted by the hospital administrator 
  fell through and he began to look for someone to adopt her.Â  He found the Bergstroms.Â  
  Padgett did not file adoption papers and the Bergstroms never obtained legal 
  custody of the baby.Â  Bergstrom declared that she lived in an R.V. with the 
  Bergstroms and their two other children.Â  They moved from campground to campground 
  in various states.
The Colorado state authorities placed Bergstrom in protective custody when she 
  was eleven years old because Mrs. Bergstromâ€™s boyfriend had taken nude photographs 
  of her.Â  When Bergstrom was fourteen, Colorado authorities found that her birth 
  certificate had been fraudulently altered and referred the case to South Carolina 
  authorities to investigate.Â  Detective David Cribb began investigating the birth 
  certificate and found that Daly was Bergstromâ€™s natural mother.Â  After conducting 
  DNA tests to verify that Daly was the mother, the Colorado authorities released 
  Bergstrom to Dalyâ€™s custody when Bergstrom was fifteen years old.
Â Bergstrom filed suit against the hospital seeking to recover damages under theories 
  of negligence and intentional infliction of emotional distress.Â  The hospital 
  filed a Rule 12, SCRCP motion to dismiss the claims.Â  The Circuit Court granted 
  the hospitalâ€™s motion to dismiss the intentional infliction of emotional distress 
  cause of action, denied the motion to dismiss the negligence claim, and found 
  that any recovery available to Bergstrom was limited to $100,000 pursuant to 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-7-50.Â  During the trial, the Circuit Court granted the hospitalâ€™s 
  directed verdict motion on the negligence claim.
LAW/ANALYSIS
 I.   Bergstromâ€™s Negligence Claim
Bergstrom argues the Circuit Court erred when it granted the hospitalâ€™s directed 
  verdict motion on her negligence claim.Â  We disagree.
When reviewing a grant of directed verdict, this Court must determine whether 
  a verdict for the nonmoving party would have been reasonably possible under 
  the facts of the case.Â  Hanahan v. Simpson, 326 S.C. 140, 485 S.E.2d 
  903 (1997).Â  This Court should view the evidence and all the reasonable inferences 
  drawn from the evidence in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party but 
  must also consider facts which are unfavorable to the nonmoving party.Â  Love 
  v. Gamble, 316 S.C. 203, 448 S.E.2d 876 (Ct. App. 1994).Â  The issue must 
  be submitted to a jury whenever there is material evidence tending to establish 
  the issue in the mind of a reasonable juror.Â  Hanahan, 326 S.C. at 149, 
  485 S.E.2d at 908.Â  However, this rule does not authorize submission of speculative, 
  theoretical and hypothetical views to the jury.Â  Id.Â  When only one reasonable 
  inference can be deduced from the evidence, the question becomes one of law 
  for the court.Â  Id.
In order to establish a claim for negligence, the plaintiff must prove the following 
  elements: (1) a duty of care owed by the defendant to the plaintiff; (2) a breach 
  of that duty by the defendantâ€™s negligent act or omission; (3) resulting in 
  damages to the plaintiff; and (4) the damages proximately resulted from the 
  breach of duty.Â  Thomasko v. Poole, 349 S.C. 7, 561 S.E.2d 597 (2002).Â  
  An essential element in a cause of action for negligence is the existence of 
  a legal duty of care owed by the defendant to the plaintiff.Â  Bishop v. South 
  Carolina Depâ€™t of Mental Health, 331 S.C. 79, 502 S.E.2d 78 (1998).
Bergstrom contends the hospital policies governing adoptions created a special 
  relationship between her and the hospital thereby imposing a duty upon the hospital 
  to follow the procedures.Â  She alleges the hospital breached its duty when it 
  failed to allow Daly to see her, failed to have Daly sign a permit to release 
  the baby for adoption, and failed to make a special service arrangement which 
  it was required to do if the mother had not made previous arrangements.Â  We 
  disagree.Â  Any duty which the policies created was between the hospital and 
  the mother, not the hospital and the child.Â  
Bergstrom cites several cases in support of her argument.Â  The cited cases are 
  not persuasive.Â  Adoptive Parents v. Biological Parents, 315 S.C. 535, 
  446 S.E.2d 404 (1994), interprets the special and unusual circumstances clause 
  contained in the South Carolina Adoption Act which must be satisfied in order 
  for prospective out-of-state adoptive parents to adopt a baby born in South 
  Carolina.Â  The case does not discuss duties of a hospital to a baby who may 
  be placed for adoption.
Bergstrom 
  relies on Sloan v. Edgewood Sanatorium, Inc., 225 S.C. 1, 80 S.E.2d 348 
  (1954), which held a psychiatric hospital owed a duty of care to properly supervise 
  and treat a suicidal patient and was potentially liable for damages when the 
  patient committed suicide while under its care.Â  This case fails to support 
  the argument that the hospital owed a duty to Bergstrom under the facts of the 
  present case.
Although certain adoption policies were not followed by the hospital, the hospital 
  believed it was acting in accordance with Dalyâ€™s wishes.Â  The medical charts 
  for Daly indicated that Padgett was the attorney who was handling the adoption, 
  obviating the need for the hospital to make a â€œsocial service referralâ€ if the 
  mother had not made other arrangements.Â  Alice Rawlinson, the Director of Women 
  and Childrenâ€™s Services for the hospital, conceded the hospital had an obligation 
  to the baby to make certain the baby was released to the birth mother or her 
  designated agent.Â  That was done in this case.Â  Daly signed a form which allowed 
  the baby to be released to Joel Padgett as her designated representative and 
  the hospital did not breach this duty.Â  Any liability the hospital may have 
  for not allowing Daly to see the baby in accordance with its policies is a possible 
  cause of action which lies with Daly and not with Bergstrom.
The duty 
  between the hospital and Bergstrom was to make certain the hospital followed 
  the wishes of Daly regarding the placement of Bergstrom.Â  Daly indicated she 
  had an attorney who was handling the adoption, never asked any employee or representative 
  of the hospital for aid regarding the adoption, and signed a form authorizing 
  the release of Bergstrom to Padgett.Â  The hospital satisfied its duty.
 II.  Proximate Cause
Even 
  if we were to find the hospital breached a duty that existed between it and 
  Bergstrom, Bergstrom could not satisfy the requirement that she prove her damages 
  were proximately caused by the hospital.
Negligence 
  is not actionable unless it is a proximate cause of the injury.Â  Bishop v. 
  South Carolina Depâ€™t of Mental Health, 331 S.C. 79, 502 S.E.2d 78 (1998).Â  
  To prove proximate cause, the plaintiff must demonstrate both causation in fact 
  and legal cause.Â  Parks v. Characters Night Club, 345 S.C. 484, 548 S.E.2d 
  605 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  Causation in fact is proved by establishing the injury 
  would not have occurred but for the defendantâ€™s negligence.Â  Russ v. Blanchard, 
  310 S.C. 375, 426 S.E.2d 802 (1993).
The law 
  regarding legal cause has been recently summarized in Trivelas v. South Carolina 
  Depâ€™t of Transp., 348 S.C. 125, 558 S.E.2d 271 (Ct. App. 2001):Â  

Legal cause turns on the issue of 
  foreseeability.Â  An injury is foreseeable if it is the natural and probable 
  consequence of a breach of duty.Â  Foreseeability is not determined from hindsight, 
  but rather from the defendantâ€™s perspective at the time of the alleged breach.Â  
  It is not necessary for a plaintiff to demonstrate the defendant should have 
  forseen the particular event which occurred but merely that the defendant should 
  have forseen his or her negligence would probably cause injury to someone.Â  
  

Id. 
  at 136, 558 S.E.2d at 276 (citations omitted).
In Works v. Arlington Memorial Hospital, 782 S.W.2d 309 (Tex. App. 1989), 
  a childâ€™s adoptive parents brought a negligence action against the hospital 
  alleging the child was abused by other prospective adoptive parents after the 
  childâ€™s release from the hospital.Â  The specific allegations of wrongdoing in 
  Works are similar to this case and are as follows:

Arlington Memorial 
  Hospital records and bills, available to the hospital employees at the time 
  of Baby Doeâ€™s birth, indicated that [an attorney at law] had agreed to be responsible 
  for the biological motherâ€™s hospital expenses and that the child was to be put 
  up for adoption.Â  Though this information was known, the hospital failed to 
  refer the biological mother to any proper child placement agency or social service 
  agency.Â  After its birth, the child was taken from the hospital grounds by [the 
  attorney] . . . . Hospital personnel were present at the time the [attorney] 
  . . . took the baby.Â  After being turned over to [third parties] by [the attorney], 
  the baby was severely abused.Â  The hospital failed to involve its own social 
  work department at any point while the natural mother was in the hospital.Â  
  The hospital failed to investigate the circumstances surrounding the discharge 
  of the biological mother.Â  The hospital failed to ascertain that proper conservatorship 
  papers were held by those persons taking the baby from the hospital grounds.Â  
  It is asserted that had the hospital acted properly, the opportunity would not 
  have arisen for the child to be abused.

Id. 
  at 311.
Additional facts in the Works case indicated the biological mother signed 
  the release form for the child and turned the baby over to the attorney, that 
  no person affiliated with the hospital had any involvement with the adoption 
  of the child, and no one at the hospital attempted to influence the biological 
  mother in connection with her decision about the adoption.Â  Id.Â  The 
  Court of Appeals of Texas relied upon expert testimony and determined:

[A] hospital 
  is not supposed to be able to see the future like a fortune teller with a crystal 
  ball; . . . [the expert] was not capable of seeing the future like a fortune 
  teller with a crystal ball--that even she could not have predicted, based on 
  the type of information available at the time the child . . . left the hospital, 
  that it would be mistreated in the way it allegedly was according to the Worksâ€™ 
  pleadings. . . . [The expert] â€œwouldnâ€™t have tried toâ€ make such predictions.Â  
  [The expert] agreed that for any two people to take a little, innocent baby 
  and beat it up would be aberrational and abnormal behavior and that it would 
  be unforeseeable to [the expert], or to anybody, including the people at the 
  hospital . . . that this would occur.

Id. 
  at 314.Â Â  
In ruling that the plaintiff failed to establish proximate cause, the Works 
  court articulated: â€œwe conclude as a matter of law that, in light of all the 
  attending circumstances . . ., the injuries suffered by the [child] could not 
  reasonably have been anticipated by the hospital as a consequence of any asserted 
  negligent act or omission alleged against it.Â  In short, we conclude that the 
  hospital could not have foreseen the danger to [the child].â€Â  Id.
We are persuaded by the analysis in the Works case and find Bergstrom 
  failed to establish the hospitalâ€™s actions were the cause of her injury.Â  At 
  the time Bergstrom was born, the hospital could not have foreseen that following 
  Dalyâ€™s instructions to release Bergstrom to Padgett would result in her failed 
  adoption by nomadic parents who sexually exploited her.Â  Bergstrom failed to 
  establish legal cause.Â  Concomitantly, the Circuit Court did not err when it 
  granted the hospitalâ€™s directed verdict motion.
III.Â  Bergstormâ€™s Intentional Infliction 
  of Emotional Distress Claim
Bergstrom maintains the Circuit Court erred when it granted the hospitalâ€™s Rule 
  12, SCRCP motion to dismiss the intentional infliction of emotional distress 
  claim.Â  We disagree.
Under Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP, a defendant may move to dismiss based on a failure 
  to state facts sufficient to constitute a cause of action.Â  Baird v. Charleston 
  County, 333 S.C. 519, 511 S.E.2d 69 (1999).Â  Generally, in considering a 
  12(b)(6) motion, the trial court must base its ruling solely upon allegations 
  set forth on the face of the complaint.Â  Id.; Stiles v. Onorato, 
  318 S.C. 297, 457 S.E.2d 601 (1995).Â  If the facts and inferences drawn from 
  the facts alleged on the complaint would entitle the plaintiff to relief on 
  any theory, then the grant of a motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim 
  is improper.Â  Baird, 333 S.C. at 527, 511 S.E.2d at 73.Â  In deciding 
  whether the trial court properly granted the motion to dismiss, this Court must 
  consider whether the complaint, viewed in the light most favorable to the plaintiff, 
  states any valid claim for relief.Â  See Gentry v. Yonce, 337 S.C. 
  1, 522 S.E.2d 137 (1999).Â  A motion to dismiss under Rule 12(b)(6) should not 
  be granted if facts alleged and inferences reasonably deducible therefrom entitle 
  the plaintiff to relief under any theory.Â  Id.
A plaintiff must satisfy the following elements to state a claim of intentional 
  infliction of emotional distress: (1) the defendant intentionally or recklessly 
  inflicted severe emotional distress, or was certain or substantially certain 
  that such distress would result from his conduct; (2) the conduct was so extreme 
  and outrageous as to exceed all possible bounds of decency and must be regarded 
  as atrocious and utterly intolerable in a civilized community; (3) the actions 
  of the defendant caused the plaintiffâ€™s emotional distress; and (4) the emotional 
  distress suffered by the plaintiff was so severe that no reasonable person could 
  be expected to endure it.Â  Upchurch v. New York Times Co., 314 S.C. 531, 
  431 S.E.2d 558 (1993); Ford v. Hutson, 276 S.C. 157, 276 S.E.2d 776 (1981).
Even 
  viewing the facts and inferences therefrom alleged in the complaint in the light 
  most favorable Bergstrom, we find the complaint failed to state the elements 
  necessary to sustain an intentional infliction of emotional distress cause of 
  action.Â  As stated above when discussing Bergstromâ€™s negligence claim, the facts 
  failed to show that the hospitalâ€™s conduct was the proximate cause of Bergstromâ€™s 
  injuries.Â  There was no way the hospital was certain or substantially certain 
  that releasing Bergstrom to Padgett as Daly instructed on the release form would 
  result in Bergstromâ€™s abuse by her putative adoptive parents.Â  Furthermore, 
  we cannot say that the hospitalâ€™s conduct of releasing the baby per Dalyâ€™s instruction 
  exceeded the bounds of common decency.Â  The Circuit Court did not err when it 
  granted the hospitalâ€™s motion to dismiss the intentional infliction of emotional 
  distress cause of action.
CONCLUSION
We rule that, 
  in light of all the attending circumstances, the hospital did not owe a duty 
  of care to Bergstrom.Â  Additionally, Bergstrom failed to establish that any 
  alleged damages were proximately caused by the hospital.
Elementally, the 
  complaint of Bergstrom did not state a cause of action for intentional infliction 
  of emotional distress.
Because we have 
  ruled the hospital is not liable to the plaintiff on any theory, we do not reach 
  the issue in regard to capping the hospitalâ€™s liability at $100,000.Â  Accordingly, 
  we
 
  AFFIRM.
 
  CONNOR and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

 
  
  [1] Â  Debbie Dalyâ€™s last name is spelled two different ways in 
    the record.Â  It is spelled â€œDalyâ€ and â€œDaley.â€Â  In the appellantâ€™s brief, 
    her last name is spelled â€œDaley.â€Â  In the respondentâ€™s brief, her last name 
    is spelled â€œDaly.â€Â  We use the â€œDalyâ€ spelling throughout the opinion.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Rebecca M. Blanton, Respondent,
v.
Jimmy P. Stathos, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Pickens County
Charles B. Simmons, Jr.,
Special Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3553
Â Â Â Â Â  Heard September 11, 2002 â€“ Filed September 30, 2002

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
James M. Robinson, of Easley, for Appellant.
Craig H. Allen, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  


 ANDERSON, J.:Â  Jimmy P. Stathos 
  appeals the Circuit Courtâ€™s finding that the agreement between him and Rebecca 
  M. Blanton involves interstate commerce and, therefore, is subject to the Federal 
  Arbitration Act (â€œFAAâ€), 9 U.S.C.A. Â§ 2 (1970).Â  We affirm.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Stathos contracted with Blanton, whereby Blanton 
  agreed to provide design, drawing, and architectural services for Stathos in 
  the construction of a restaurant in Seneca, South Carolina.Â  The contract was 
  a standard American Institute of Architects (â€œAIAâ€) contract, which contained 
  a clause providing for the arbitration of disputes.Â  Both parties agree the 
  contract does not contain the notice of arbitration required by S.C. Code Ann. 
  Â§ 15-48-10(a) (Supp. 2001). 
Blanton began drafting the designs and drawings 
  for the construction of the restaurant.Â  In performing this service, she consulted 
  with several out-of-state companies regarding specifications of components that 
  would be required for the project.Â  However, prior to Blantonâ€™s completion of 
  her duties under the contract, Stathos terminated the contract.Â  Procurement 
  of the materials and construction of the restaurant had not begun at the time 
  of the breach of contract. 
Blanton submitted her claim to the American Arbitration 
  Association pursuant to the terms of the arbitration provision of the AIA contract.Â  
  Notice was served on Stathos by certified mail.Â  Stathos did not reply to the 
  notice nor did he participate in the arbitration process.Â  The arbitrator awarded 
  Blanton her requested damages of $9,669.80 and assessed Stathos $243.98 in arbitratorâ€™s 
  fees.Â  
Blanton, pro se, filed 
  a copy of the arbitration award with the Pickens County Clerk of Court.Â  The 
  award was erroneously entered on the Judgment Roll.Â  Thereafter, Stathos filed 
  a Motion to be Relieved from Judgment, and Blanton filed a Motion for Confirmation 
  of the Arbitration Award. 
The Circuit Court found the contract between Stathos 
  and Blanton evidenced a transaction involving interstate commerce and concluded 
  the FAA applied.Â  Stathosâ€™ Motion to be Relieved from Judgment was denied and 
  Blantonâ€™s Motion for Confirmation of the Arbitration Award was granted.Â  The 
  Circuit Court judge entered a judgment in favor of Blanton for the $9,669.80 
  awarded by the arbitrator, plus the $243.98 in arbitratorâ€™s fees.Â  Stathosâ€™ 
  Motion to Reconsider was denied.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Section 15-48-10(a)
Stathos asserts the AIA contract does 
  not meet the standard of the South Carolina Arbitration Act and its notice provision, 
  which is found in Â§ 15-48-10(a) (Supp. 2001).Â  We agree.

Section 15-48-10(a) requires: 
Notice that a contract is subject to arbitration pursuant 
  to this chapter shall be typed in underlined capital letters, or rubber-stamped 
  prominently, on the first page of the contract and unless such notice is displayed 
  thereon the contract shall not be subject to arbitration.Â  

These elements are to be strictly adhered 
  to in order to satisfy the notice requirements.Â  See Zabinski v. Bright 
  Acres Assocs., 346 S.C. 580, 553 S.E.2d 110 (2001); Soil Remediation 
  Co. v. Nu-Way Envtl., Inc., 323 S.C. 454, 476 S.E.2d 149 (1996).Â  No other 
  variation is acceptable.Â  Zabinski, 346 S.C. at 589, 533 S.E.2d at 114.
The contract in this case contains an arbitration 
  clause for settling disputes.Â  Both parties concede the contract contains no 
  notice that it is subject to arbitration as required by section 15-48-10(a).Â  
  Under South Carolina law, the arbitration provision would not be enforceable.
II.Â  The Preemption 
  Mandate of FAA
The inquiry does not conclude with the 
  application of South Carolina law.Â  â€œInextricably linked with the question of 
  the applicability of section 15-48-10(a), is the impact of the FAA.â€Â  Zabinski
